en:
**Solar noon** â€” the Sun transits the local meridian and reaches its highest altitude for the day.

- Not necessarily at 12:00 clock time
- Depends on longitude and the **equation of time**

en:
**Golden hour** â€” period shortly after sunrise and before sunset when the Sun is low and light is warm and soft.

- Typically around **0â€“6Â°** altitude; exact definitions vary by source and conditions
- Warm tones, long shadows, low contrast; favored for photography

More: [Wikipedia â€“ Golden hour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_hour_(photography))
de:

en:
**Blue hour** â€” cool, blue ambient light **before sunrise** and **after sunset** when the Sun is below the horizon.

- Often approximated when the Sun is **4â€“8Â° below** the horizon
- Deep blue hues; city lights and sky balance well â€” ideal for urban scenes

More: [Wikipedia â€“ Blue hour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_hour)

en:
**Day length** â€” time from **sunrise** to **sunset** (upper limb crossing the horizon).

- Does not include twilight periods
- Varies with latitude and date; affected by refraction and solar radius

More: [Wikipedia â€“ Day length](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Day_length)

en:
**Altitude** â€” angle of the Sun above the horizon (negative values are below it).

- Range: 0Â° (horizon) â€¦ +90Â° (zenith)
- With **azimuth** it forms horizontal coordinates

More: [Horizontal coordinate system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_coordinate_system)

en:
**Azimuth** â€” compass bearing of the Sun measured from **north** clockwise along the horizon.

- 0Â° = North, 90Â° = East, 180Â° = South, 270Â° = West

en:
**Right Ascension (RA)** â€” sky longitude measured eastward from the vernal equinox along the celestial equator.

- Unit: hours (0â€“24 h), minutes, seconds; **1 h = 15Â°**
- Pairs with **Declination (Dec)** for celestial coordinates
- Example: *05h 35m 17s*

More: [Wikipedia â€“ Right ascension](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_ascension)

en:
**Sunâ€“Earth distance** â€” current distance between Earth and the Sun, in **astronomical units (AU)**.

- Varies annually: ~**0.983 AU** at perihelion (early January) to ~**1.017 AU** at aphelion (early July)

More: [Astronomical unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit)
de:
**Entfernung Erdeâ€“Sonne** â€” aktuelle Distanz zwischen Erde und Sonne in **astronomischen Einheiten (AE)**.

en:
**Equation of Time** â€” difference between *apparent* solar time and *mean* solar time.

- Caused by Earth's orbital eccentricity and axial tilt
- Varies roughly between **âˆ’14 min** and **+16 min** over the year
- Explains why solar noon shifts from 12:00

More: [Wikipedia â€“ Equation of time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation_of_time)
de:

Mehr: [Wikipedia â€“ Zeitgleichung](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeitgleichung)

en:
**Lighting mood** â€” a concise summary of the current ambient light at your location. It blends the Sun's altitude with twilight phases to choose the most relevant label and also handles polar conditions.

- Bright daylight â€” strong direct sun
- Daylight â€” natural light, not at peak
- Golden hour â€” warm, soft light
- Blue hour â€” cool, bluish ambience
- Nautical twilight â€” very dim, horizon barely visible
- Night â€” astronomically dark sky
- Polar day / Polar night â€” continuous daylight/darkness

Tip: Use as a quick indicator; see the other entries for definitions.
de:

- Helles Tageslicht â€” starke direkte Sonne
- Tageslicht â€” natÃ¼rliches Licht, nicht am Maximum
- Goldene Stunde â€” warm, weich
- Blaue Stunde â€” kÃ¼hl, blÃ¤ulich
- Nautische DÃ¤mmerung â€” sehr dunkel, Horizont kaum sichtbar
- Nacht â€” astronomische Dunkelheit
- Polartag / Polarnacht â€” durchgehend Tag/Nacht

Hinweis: Eignet sich als schnelle Orientierung; Details stehen in den jeweiligen EintrÃ¤gen.

en:
**Sun position** â€” current solar direction at your selected location.

- **ðŸ•’ Time zone:** shows either your **current local time zone** or the **time zone of the selected location**.
  Tap the **clock icon** to toggle between them.
  Example: ðŸ•’ MEZ â€” Europe/Berlin
- **Elevation:** angle above or below the horizon (0Â° = horizon, 90Â° = zenith; negative = below)
- **Azimuth (north-based):** 0Â° = N, 90Â° = E, 180Â° = S, 270Â° = W
- **Location:** defines the reference point for these values; changing location or time updates them accordingly.
